title: 112_s3214
content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms like "Administration" and "small business concern" under the Small Business Act. It also establishes an Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education in the Administration develops and provides entrepreneurial information, education, and resources for prospective entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The Director of the Office reports to the Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development and manages online courses and resources for entrepreneurs. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education in the Administration oversees youth entrepreneurship programs, coordinates with partners on financial literacy, and provides assistance to entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education oversees youth entrepreneurship programs and provides assistance to individuals and foreign dignitaries interested in small business concerns. Additionally, a National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program will be established to provide grants for technical assistance to nonprofit organizations. The Administration partners with nonprofit organizations to provide technical assistance to schools for entrepreneurship programs. Nonprofits must submit an application detailing project goals, partners, and other necessary information to receive a grant. A report is required within one year of receiving the grant. Nonprofit organizations receiving grants must submit a report on individuals assisted, jobs created, and grant usage details. $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2013-2015. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report on best practices within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report to the Senate and House committees on best practices of entrepreneurial education programs in the US, including national, regional, state, and local programs, within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report on entrepreneurial education programs must include best practices from the Federal Government, State and local governments, nonprofit organizations, and private sector groups. The Master of Business Administration Scholarship Pilot Program is established. The Administrator may award up to 100 scholarships of $1,500 each to MBA students on a competitive basis. Recipients must provide free assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. At least 50% of recipients must be students at higher education institutions. The scholarship program supports small business projects for MBA students at higher education institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. Recipients work on various projects with mentor support to connect academic studies with practical assistance. Students receiving scholarships must provide information on the use of assistance and employment status for 3 years after graduation. Failure to comply results in the scholarship being treated as a loan. The Administrator may award scholarships that must be repaid as a Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loan with interest. $200,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2015. No scholarships can be awarded after September 30, 2015. SEC. 5. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify issues, sponsor competitions for small businesses, and collaborate with universities. The Administrator will organize a national conference to promote a competition for research and business plans that address identified issues. The Administrator will organize a national conference to present selected research and business plans from regional administrators. A panel of 11 employees will choose the best plan from each region addressing identified issues. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to selected plans from regional offices. Recipients must submit a report on grant usage within a year. $750,000 is authorized for Administrator's use. The Administrator will receive $750,000 for implementing this section. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days with recommendations for legislation on forgiving and deferring student loans to support youth entrepreneurship and business formation.
